DOC.HEAD: Only Violence Can Bring Down Ceausescu
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In contrast to the largely peaceful changes in other Eastern European countries, President Nicolae Ceausescu of Romania appears determined to use force to defend his hard-line regime. Ceausescu, 71, the most senior Soviet bloc leader after 24 years in power, has said reform-minded Communists elsewhere have betrayed their people by refusing to defend Marxist orthodoxy. Ceausescu's refusal to embrace change has isolated him from all his Warsaw Pact allies. Some analysts say he is seeking stronger ties with rigid Communist systems similarly opposed to political reform, particularly North Korea, Cuba and China. His leadership is based on a family dynasty with some 40 relatives reportedly placed in key state and party jobs. His wife Elena, virtual second-in-command in Romania, is a Politburo member and first vice premier. One of Ceausescu's brothers, Ilie, is an army general and deputy defense minister. Another brother, Nicolae Andruta, is a police general and deputy interior minister and another brother, Ion, is in charge of economic planning. His youngest son, Nicu, 39, is a Politburo candidate member and party chief of Sibiu region in southern Transylvania. ``Romania is a showcase for any repressive totalitarian state. The harsher the repression, the more violent the public upheaval it brings about and the greater the desire to take revenge on leaders,'' Ion Ratiu, chairman of the London-based World Union of Free Romanians, said Monday. Since he became party leader in 1965, Ceausescu has exercised absolute power and carried out a foreign policy independent of the Soviet Union. While that maverick stance won him praise and credits from the West, Ceausescu kept Romanians under iron-fisted control. Now, with reform ascendent in the rest of the Warsaw Pact, the harsh Romanian stand draws condemnation from abroad. About 30,000 coal miners went on strike in the Jiu Valley in 1977 and 10,000 workers demonstrated in the city of Brasov in 1987 demanding freedom, better living conditions and Ceausescu's ouster. Police arrested hundreds of demonstrators and their leaders disappeared. An extensive secret police force keeps strict control on religious and political expression, and dissent is quickly crushed, making chances for peaceful change in Romania seem remote. But poverty and despair engendered by economic problems and political repressions could cause people to risk direct confrontations with armed forces, as in Timisoara now. Unlike recent protests in Prague and East Germany, witnessed and reported by the Western media, demonstrations in Romania have taken place well outside the public eye. The Western reporters permitted into the country in recent years have been kept under close watch, and police have detained journalists and even diplomats attempting to visit the country's few dissidents. Romania has closed its borders and barred most foreigners from entering the country in an apparent attempt to prevent the spread of news about the Timisoara protest, the largest demonstration against Ceausescu's policies since the Brasov riots. Romania has little tradition of democratic rule. After five centuries under the Ottoman Turks, Romania won independence in 1877, becoming first a monarchy, then, during the Second World War, an ally of the Nazis. The last monarch, King Michael, was forced to abdicate in December 1947 under threat of civil war and pressure from the Kremlin and its Romanian Communist allies.
